page.title: 11Farming west: FINTRY
page.content:
{With sheep and livestock rearing the {general pattern on the higher land, {the intensive agriculture in the area {is in a number of substantial dairy {farms}in the west end of the valley. Milking between 90 and 125 cows each - the more productive{Friesian}and {Holstein}breeds have ousted the native Ayrshire cows - and using mechanised milking, feeding and feed production systems, the farms reflect a national trend of declining farm labour.
One of the larger units, with 3 men other than the farmer and his family is the largest employer. This unit of 640 acres, milks 125 cows, produces annually milk worth Â£130,000, 150 tonnes of barley, 100 tonnes of hay, 1500 tonnes of grass silage and 70 to 80 bullocks and heifers for sale as forward stores of beef.
